segment.source: Use Orchestrator runbooks with MDT (Windows 10)
segment.target: Use Orchestrator runbooks with MDT (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic will show you how to integrate Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 Orchestrator with MDT to replace the existing web services that are used in deployment solutions.
segment.target: This topic will show you how to integrate Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 Orchestrator with MDT to replace the existing web services that are used in deployment solutions.

segment.source: Use Orchestrator runbooks with MDT
segment.target: Use Orchestrator runbooks with MDT

segment.source: This topic will show you how to integrate Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 Orchestrator with MDT to replace the existing web services that are used in deployment solutions.
segment.target: This topic will show you how to integrate Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 Orchestrator with MDT to replace the existing web services that are used in deployment solutions.

segment.source: MDT can integrate with System Center 2012 R2 Orchestrator, which is a component that ties the Microsoft System Center products together, as well as other products from both Microsoft and third-party vendors.
segment.target: MDT can integrate with System Center 2012 R2 Orchestrator, which is a component that ties the Microsoft System Center products together, as well as other products from both Microsoft and third-party vendors.

segment.source: The difference between using Orchestrator and "normal" web services, is that with Orchestrator you have a rich drag-and-drop style interface when building the solution, and little or no coding is required.
segment.target: The difference between using Orchestrator and "normal" web services, is that with Orchestrator you have a rich drag-and-drop style interface when building the solution, and little or no coding is required.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If you are licensed to use Orchestrator, we highly recommend that you start using it.
segment.target: If you are licensed to use Orchestrator, we highly recommend that you start using it.

segment.source: To find out more about licensing options for System Center 2012 R2 and Orchestrator, visit the System Center 2012 R2 website.
segment.target: To find out more about licensing options for System Center 2012 R2 and Orchestrator, visit the System Center 2012 R2 website.

segment.source: Orchestrator terminology
segment.target: Orchestrator terminology

segment.source: Before diving into the core details, here is a quick course in Orchestrator terminology:
segment.target: Before diving into the core details, here is a quick course in Orchestrator terminology:

segment.source: Orchestrator Server.
segment.target: Orchestrator Server.

segment.source: This is a server that executes runbooks.
segment.target: This is a server that executes runbooks.

segment.source: Runbooks.
segment.target: Runbooks.

segment.source: A runbook is similar to a task sequence; it is a series of instructions based on conditions.
segment.target: A runbook is similar to a task sequence; it is a series of instructions based on conditions.

segment.source: Runbooks consist of workflow activities; an activity could be Copy File, Get User from Active Directory, or even Write to Database.
segment.target: Runbooks consist of workflow activities; an activity could be Copy File, Get User from Active Directory, or even Write to Database.

segment.source: Orchestrator Designer.
segment.target: Orchestrator Designer.

segment.source: This is where you build the runbooks.
segment.target: This is where you build the runbooks.

segment.source: In brief, you do that by creating an empty runbook, dragging in the activities you need, and then connecting them in a workflow with conditions and subscriptions.
segment.target: In brief, you do that by creating an empty runbook, dragging in the activities you need, and then connecting them in a workflow with conditions and subscriptions.

segment.source: Subscriptions.
segment.target: Subscriptions.

segment.source: These are variables that come from an earlier activity in the runbook.
segment.target: These are variables that come from an earlier activity in the runbook.

segment.source: So if you first execute an activity in which you type in a computer name, you can then subscribe to that value in the next activity.
segment.target: So if you first execute an activity in which you type in a computer name, you can then subscribe to that value in the next activity.

segment.source: All these variables are accumulated during the execution of the runbook.
segment.target: All these variables are accumulated during the execution of the runbook.

segment.source: Orchestrator Console.
segment.target: Orchestrator Console.

segment.source: This is the Microsoft Silverlight-based web page you can use interactively to execute runbooks.
segment.target: This is the Microsoft Silverlight-based web page you can use interactively to execute runbooks.

segment.source: The console listens to TCP port 81 by default.
segment.target: The console listens to TCP port 81 by default.

segment.source: Orchestrator web services.
segment.target: Orchestrator web services.

segment.source: These are the web services you use in the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit to execute runbooks during deployment.
segment.target: These are the web services you use in the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit to execute runbooks during deployment.

segment.source: The web services listen to TCP port 82 by default.
segment.target: The web services listen to TCP port 82 by default.

segment.source: Integration packs.
segment.target: Integration packs.

segment.source: These provide additional workflow activities you can import to integrate with other products or solutions, like the rest of Active Directory, other System Center 2012 R2 products, or Microsoft Exchange Server, to name a few.
segment.target: These provide additional workflow activities you can import to integrate with other products or solutions, like the rest of Active Directory, other System Center 2012 R2 products, or Microsoft Exchange Server, to name a few.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: To find and download additional integration packs, see Integration Packs for System Center 2012 - Orchestrator.
segment.target: To find and download additional integration packs, see Integration Packs for System Center 2012 - Orchestrator.

segment.source: Create a sample runbook
segment.target: Create a sample runbook

segment.source: This section assumes you have Orchestrator 2012 R2 installed on a server named OR01.
segment.target: This section assumes you have Orchestrator 2012 R2 installed on a server named OR01.

segment.source: In this section, you create a sample runbook, which is used to log some of the MDT deployment information into a text file on OR01.
segment.target: In this section, you create a sample runbook, which is used to log some of the MDT deployment information into a text file on OR01.

segment.source: On OR01, using File Explorer, create the E:Logfile folder, and grant Users modify permissions (NTFS).
segment.target: On OR01, using File Explorer, create the E:Logfile folder, and grant Users modify permissions (NTFS).

segment.source: In the E:Logfile folder, create the DeployLog.txt file.
segment.target: In the E:Logfile folder, create the DeployLog.txt file.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Make sure File Explorer is configured to show known file extensions so the file is not named DeployLog.txt.txt.
segment.target: Make sure File Explorer is configured to show known file extensions so the file is not named DeployLog.txt.txt.

segment.source: figure 23
segment.target: figure 23

segment.source: Figure 23.
segment.target: Figure 23.

segment.source: The DeployLog.txt file.
segment.target: The DeployLog.txt file.

segment.source: Using System Center 2012 R2 Orchestrator Runbook Designer, in the Runbooks node, create the 1.0 MDT folder.
segment.target: Using System Center 2012 R2 Orchestrator Runbook Designer, in the Runbooks node, create the 1.0 MDT folder.

segment.source: figure 24
segment.target: figure 24

segment.source: Figure 24.
segment.target: Figure 24.

segment.source: Folder created in the Runbooks node.
segment.target: Folder created in the Runbooks node.

segment.source: In the Runbooks node, right-click the 1.0 MDT folder, and select New / Runbook.
segment.target: In the Runbooks node, right-click the 1.0 MDT folder, and select New / Runbook.

segment.source: On the ribbon bar, click Check Out.
segment.target: On the ribbon bar, click Check Out.

segment.source: Right-click the New Runbook label, select Rename, and assign the name MDT Sample.
segment.target: Right-click the New Runbook label, select Rename, and assign the name MDT Sample.

segment.source: Add (using a drag-and-drop operation) the following items from the Activities list to the middle pane:
segment.target: Add (using a drag-and-drop operation) the following items from the Activities list to the middle pane:

segment.source: Runbook Control / Initialize Data
segment.target: Runbook Control / Initialize Data

segment.source: Text File Management / Append Line
segment.target: Text File Management / Append Line

segment.source: Connect Initialize Data to Append Line.
segment.target: Connect Initialize Data to Append Line.

segment.source: figure 25
segment.target: figure 25

segment.source: Figure 25.
segment.target: Figure 25.

segment.source: Activities added and connected.
segment.target: Activities added and connected.

segment.source: Right-click the Initialize Data activity, and select Properties
segment.target: Right-click the Initialize Data activity, and select Properties

segment.source: On the Initialize Data Properties page, click Add, change Parameter 1 to OSDComputerName, and then click Finish.
segment.target: On the Initialize Data Properties page, click Add, change Parameter 1 to OSDComputerName, and then click Finish.

segment.source: figure 26
segment.target: figure 26

segment.source: Figure 26.
segment.target: Figure 26.

segment.source: The Initialize Data Properties window.
segment.target: The Initialize Data Properties window.

segment.source: Right-click the Append Line activity, and select Properties.
segment.target: Right-click the Append Line activity, and select Properties.

segment.source: On the Append Line Properties page, in the File text box, type E:LogfileDeployLog.txt.
segment.target: On the Append Line Properties page, in the File text box, type E:LogfileDeployLog.txt.

segment.source: In the File encoding drop-down list, select ASCII.
segment.target: In the File encoding drop-down list, select ASCII.

segment.source: In the Append area, right-click inside the Text text box and select Expand.
segment.target: In the Append area, right-click inside the Text text box and select Expand.

segment.source: figure 27
segment.target: figure 27

segment.source: Figure 27.
segment.target: Figure 27.

segment.source: Expanding the Text area.
segment.target: Expanding the Text area.

segment.source: In the blank text box, right-click and select Subscribe / Published Data.
segment.target: In the blank text box, right-click and select Subscribe / Published Data.

segment.source: figure 28
segment.target: figure 28

segment.source: Figure 28.
segment.target: Figure 28.

segment.source: Subscribing to data.
segment.target: Subscribing to data.

segment.source: In the Published Data window, select the OSDComputerName item, and click OK.
segment.target: In the Published Data window, select the OSDComputerName item, and click OK.

segment.source: After the {OSDComputerName from "Initialize Data"} text, type in has been deployed at and, once again, right-click and select Subscribe / Published Data.
segment.target: After the {OSDComputerName from "Initialize Data"} text, type in has been deployed at and, once again, right-click and select Subscribe / Published Data.

segment.source: In the Published Data window, select the Show common Published Data check box, select the Activity end time item, and click OK.
segment.target: In the Published Data window, select the Show common Published Data check box, select the Activity end time item, and click OK.

segment.source: figure 29
segment.target: figure 29

segment.source: Figure 29.
segment.target: Figure 29.

segment.source: The expanded text box after all subscriptions have been added.
segment.target: The expanded text box after all subscriptions have been added.

segment.source: On the Append Line Properties page, click Finish.
segment.target: On the Append Line Properties page, click Finish.

segment.source: Test the demo MDT runbook
segment.target: Test the demo MDT runbook

segment.source: After the runbook is created, you are ready to test it.
segment.target: After the runbook is created, you are ready to test it.

segment.source: On the ribbon bar, click Runbook Tester.
segment.target: On the ribbon bar, click Runbook Tester.

segment.source: Click Run, and in the Initialize Data Parameters dialog box, use the following setting and then click OK:
segment.target: Click Run, and in the Initialize Data Parameters dialog box, use the following setting and then click OK:

segment.source: OSDComputerName: PC0010
segment.target: OSDComputerName: PC0010

segment.source: Verify that all activities are green (for additional information, see each target).
segment.target: Verify that all activities are green (for additional information, see each target).

segment.source: Close the Runbook Tester.
segment.target: Close the Runbook Tester.

segment.source: On the ribbon bar, click Check In.
segment.target: On the ribbon bar, click Check In.

segment.source: figure 30
segment.target: figure 30

segment.source: Figure 30.
segment.target: Figure 30.

segment.source: All tests completed.
segment.target: All tests completed.

segment.source: Use the MDT demo runbook from MDT
segment.target: Use the MDT demo runbook from MDT

segment.source: On MDT01, using the Deployment Workbench, in the MDT Production deployment share, select the Task Sequences node, and create a folder named Orchestrator.
segment.target: On MDT01, using the Deployment Workbench, in the MDT Production deployment share, select the Task Sequences node, and create a folder named Orchestrator.

segment.source: Right-click the Orchestrator node, and select New Task Sequence.
segment.target: Right-click the Orchestrator node, and select New Task Sequence.

segment.source: Use the following settings for the New Task Sequence Wizard:
segment.target: Use the following settings for the New Task Sequence Wizard:

segment.source: Task sequence ID: OR001
segment.target: Task sequence ID: OR001

segment.source: Task sequence name: Orchestrator Sample
segment.target: Task sequence name: Orchestrator Sample

segment.source: Task sequence comments: blank
segment.target: Task sequence comments: blank

segment.source: Template: Custom Task Sequence
segment.target: Template: Custom Task Sequence

segment.source: In the Orchestrator node, double-click the Orchestrator Sample task sequence, and then select the Task Sequence tab.
segment.target: In the Orchestrator node, double-click the Orchestrator Sample task sequence, and then select the Task Sequence tab.

segment.source: Remove the default Application Install action.
segment.target: Remove the default Application Install action.

segment.source: Add a Gather action and select the Gather only local data (do not process rules) option.
segment.target: Add a Gather action and select the Gather only local data (do not process rules) option.

segment.source: After the Gather action, add a Set Task Sequence Variable action with the following settings:
segment.target: After the Gather action, add a Set Task Sequence Variable action with the following settings:

segment.source: Name: Set Task Sequence Variable
segment.target: Name: Set Task Sequence Variable

segment.source: Task Sequence Variable: OSDComputerName
segment.target: Task Sequence Variable: OSDComputerName

segment.source: Value: %hostname%
segment.target: Value: %hostname%

segment.source: After the Set Task Sequence Variable action, add a new Execute Orchestrator Runbook action with the following settings:
segment.target: After the Set Task Sequence Variable action, add a new Execute Orchestrator Runbook action with the following settings:

segment.source: Orchestrator Server: OR01.contoso.com
segment.target: Orchestrator Server: OR01.contoso.com

segment.source: Use Browse to select 1.0 MDT / MDT Sample.
segment.target: Use Browse to select 1.0 MDT / MDT Sample.

segment.source: Click OK.
segment.target: Click OK.

segment.source: figure 31
segment.target: figure 31

segment.source: Figure 31.
segment.target: Figure 31.

segment.source: The ready-made task sequence.
segment.target: The ready-made task sequence.

segment.source: Run the orchestrator sample task sequence
segment.target: Run the orchestrator sample task sequence

segment.source: Since this task sequence just starts a runbook, you can test this on the PC0001 client that you used for the MDT simulation environment.
segment.target: Since this task sequence just starts a runbook, you can test this on the PC0001 client that you used for the MDT simulation environment.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Make sure the account you are using has permissions to run runbooks on the Orchestrator server.
segment.target: Make sure the account you are using has permissions to run runbooks on the Orchestrator server.

segment.source: For more information about runbook permissions, see Runbook Permissions.
segment.target: For more information about runbook permissions, see Runbook Permissions.

segment.source: On PC0001, log on as CONTOSOMDTBA.
segment.target: On PC0001, log on as CONTOSOMDTBA.

segment.source: Using an elevated command prompt (run as Administrator), type the following command:
segment.target: Using an elevated command prompt (run as Administrator), type the following command:

segment.source: Complete the Windows Deployment Wizard using the following information:
segment.target: Complete the Windows Deployment Wizard using the following information:

segment.source: Task Sequence: Orchestrator Sample
segment.target: Task Sequence: Orchestrator Sample

segment.source: Credentials:
segment.target: Credentials:

segment.source: User Name: MDTBA
segment.target: User Name: MDTBA

segment.source: Password: P@ssw0rd
segment.target: Password: P@ssw0rd

segment.source: Domain: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain: CONTOSO

segment.source: Wait until the task sequence is completed and then verify that the DeployLog.txt file in the E:Logfile folder on OR01 was updated.
segment.target: Wait until the task sequence is completed and then verify that the DeployLog.txt file in the E:Logfile folder on OR01 was updated.

segment.source: figure 32
segment.target: figure 32

segment.source: Figure 32.
segment.target: Figure 32.

segment.source: The ready-made task sequence.
segment.target: The ready-made task sequence.
